snippet: Kidnapping is such a lucrative industry for extremists that it has reinforced their control over northern Mali and complicated plans for a campaign to take back Islamist-held territory.
abstract: Kidnapping has become a lucrative industry for extremists like Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghred in western Africa, netting them tens of millions of dollars in recent years; hefty income from ransoms from Western countries has reinforced extremist control over northern Mali and complicated plans for an African-led military campaign to take back Islamist-held territory.

byline.contributor: Maïa de la Baume contributed reporting from Paris.

lead_paragraph: Kidnapping is such a lucrative industry for extremists that it has reinforced their control over northern Mali and complicated plans for a campaign to take back Islamist-held territory.

headline.seo: Kidnappings Fuel Extremists in Western Africa
headline.main: Millions in Ransoms Fuel Militants’ Clout in West Africa
headline.print_headline: Kidnappings Fuel Extremists In West Africa

keywords.value: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
keywords.name: organizations
